comments.commentBody:
Yes, the lawsuit is a foolish idea.

However, the Speaker of the House is no fool. He is using this foolish idea to prevent an even MORE foolish idea. This is his diversion, smoke and mirrors, to keep his guys in line.

His party really wants to impeach Obama. They actually thought they were about to do it. The Speaker sidelined that idiot idea with this foolish one.

Lawyers call this "blowing smoke."
Donahue deserves to be fired.

Most of Chambers in the US are in an existential crisis as they continue to lose membership as other business networking opportunities have grown (just look at LinkedIn). The US Chamber has done little to help local chambers find new reasons for companies to join and even big chambers are suffering ( the San Francisco Chamber lost $7K in 2012 and has a negative net worth -- i.e. is in technical bankruptcy). At the same time, the top management at the US Chamber has enriched itself on generous salaries. Donahue raked in a cool $5.5 million in 2012 (of which $4.25 million was a bonus for his"great" work). SIX other execs each earned over $1 million. The US Chamber spent $11 million as well on fundraisers. Just image if the US Chamber had spent 1/2 of that money on projects that would benefit small business! The question is why the Committee of 100 didn't stand up to Donahue. I'm sure the US Chamber Board of Directors could find dozens of better qualified replacements who would consider it an honor to work on behalf of US business for a mere $300,000.

Citizen - We can't take in the children around the world who are living in dire circumstances. We need to take care of our own and our VETS!! Americans need to help our own citizens.  We are being played for suckers thanks to Obama and his policies. If there are not repercussions for these Central American countries to stop sending their poor to our country, then nothing will change.

As an American living in Costa Rica long enough to be able to tell you that the Nicaraguans that are here are largely illegal and struggling to have a slightly better life than back home.  Clean water?  Many of the provinces have established a "no new development" stance, because of insufficient rainfall and water shortages!  The province of Guanacaste, bordering Nicaragua, is in a serious draught, with farmers and ranchers suffering greatly!  Every Costa Rican with a job, or as an employer, pays into the national healthcare system (CAJA)......it is NOT FREE!  And as for the U.S. "resettlement" of others into this country.....Costa Rica is an independent democracy, not (as least completely) a puppet of the U.S.  You can put your Magic Wand away!

The other part of Obama's solution is to ask the American taxpayers for $3.7 to house, feed, clothe and educate these people. There is unused money in the Border patrol budget.
He has only used 1/4 of it so far this year. WHY???
They already get humanitarian aid. We are apparently a bunch of saps.
The sap part is true. Nothing will change as long as dems need cheap votes and repubs need cheap labor.
You're kidding right? The UN is one of the crookedest operations in the world.

An offer of humanitarian aid to the home countries in return for halting the exodus would have immediate results. This would cost way less than $3.7B.
This money should be administered under UN auspices considering the corrupt regimes. If gang violence is really the issue, aid could be used to establish "peace villages" in rural areas, protected by UN peacekeepers.
If escaping gang violence were legal grounds for refugee status, then million of people in crime-ridden US cities should be eligible.
Claims of escaping gang violence are suspicious. Half of gang members
are on the losing side of any gang war, and yes, they need a place to go.
Losing a gang war should not be grounds for admission to US as refugees.
Vetting that would be problematical, even in the home countries.
Long term assistance to these countries should be contingent upon
efforts of these nations to reduce their out of control birth rates. Direct
assistance in this regard is unfortunately against US law and needs to be changed.
Bringing them here will just make this country more like theirs and hurt our poor and minorities.

Process refugees in the home countries and then resettle them in safe areas
under UN peacekeepers.

Let cure American illegal drug appetites.  That will stop the violence and allow these people to live in peace.  Until then we must take in refugees fleeing violence caused by our illegal drug traffic.

They may well have figured to make up the losses in US consumption by gains in China and such places. But as the companies have no intention of creating middle classes by paying workers anywhere more than they must (which is little indeed in some quarters), that plan is not working out well for them. Further, even where people in China have seen modest gains in pay (exempting the wealth class there, which is small), they are disposed to saving and not to consumption--particularly with the model of what is likely when even lower-wage nations beckon corporate "job creators". The trust necessary to consume is lacking overall at present.

That bids ill for markets based on real products and services, and so the bubble financial markets and the efforts to extract corporate profits directly from government coffers (education, medical spending, military contracting, private prisons, social security) are as fierce as they have become. The gains to corporations even at that will be short-lived in the ultimate impoverishment of the middle class and the refusal of the wealth elite (including corporations) to pay taxes. But for actual commerce, the crisis is closer than that.
Extremely well put. It is concise and, with a little understanding of history, terrifying in its implications for the ordered societies we have become accustomed to, indeed depend upon.

The Chamber of Commerce, with It's echoes of Orwell, have to answer to the Gods of Commerce and those Gods are growing restless. The reason we don't have a full on recovery is due to Republican obstructionism. The stimulus is there (infrastructure repair, medicaid expansion, minimum wage, VA improvements) but austerity measures rule the day because of one party's intranscience. The Chamber backed the party that kept wages flat and corporate profits obscene. In doing so, they pleased their overlords but cut the legs out from under their customers. You would think that a chamber dedicated to commerce would have figured out by now that it's the customer who gives you the money. Not your bosses.

Mr. Benton, although I am not a wealthy stockholder, much of my retirement income is from dividends and interest.

I do not see these companies being able to raise the dividends if they are losing customers. A few majority of stockholders my get special dividends from cost cutting, but in the long run, those of us who are value investors, do not see the returns from layoffs, cheaper manufacturing, and other cost cutting.

I have watched several companies make these moves, lose customers, get bought out, loaded up with debt, put into Chapter 12, then sold to some Asian country buyer. It has not benefited us stockholders.

But is has made people like Ackman, Hurwitz and Ichan hundreds of millions, and people like me nothing.

Joanna: I want to thank you for your excellent and well articulated posts. I have agreed with every one of them. The level of emotional blackmail leveled by the open borders crowd at those of us who are sounding the alarm around this problem is overwhelming. I am so tired of being shamed. Of course, I am in the belly of the beast here in Cambridge where the academics have no idea how bad it is for the poor, working and middle classes here in this sanctuary city and elsewhere who have to compete with a large undocumented and underground workforce in a climate where jobs are scare.

Like you I voted for Obama AND stumped for him. And I too am on board with him on every other issue but he has lost me on this one. I feel betrayed. The blatant pandering to the La Raza, Jorge Ramos crowd is sickening. I am now a registered Independent (possibly the only one in this town).

I have compassion for people who find themselves in hideous and desperate situations all over the world and support any help that can be pro-offered to help raise these populations out of destitution. However, a massive import of these populations into this country to be supported by a dwindling middle and working class makes no sense and is tone deaf to the very real needs of a citizenry that is still reeling from the wholesale export of many of our jobs and the gutting of our economy by Wall Street. There is nothing "progressive" and humane about open borders when so many of our citizens are suffering.

There are many things in life we can't control, including our date of birth and the date we start investing in the stock market. Other things we can't much control include our date of death, whether our spouse runs off with someone else, whether our kids are Harvard material, just average, or cold-blooded murderers, whether our employment is terminated without cause, and on and on.

All we can do in the face of all this stuff is our best. As far as financial stuff is concerned, I would say one's best ought to include saving for a rainy day, saving for retirement, educating oneself about investments and trying to invest intelligently, and diversifying. Beyond that, there's not much you can do, and I personally don't think it's something worth getting worked up about.

I voted for Obama's second term. Since then I have greatly been disappointed in several things:

His handling of the situations in Iraq and Syria.

The drone program in Ethiopia and Afghanistan, which has cost the life of many civilians and done nothing to erode militant support, in fact it has helped fuel support for radicals.

The NSA scandal, which has helped to strip away civil rights.

Prosecution of whistle blowers.

A complete caving to lobbyist from the oil industry, especially BP.

Besides the health care over hall, I really can't point to anything that Obama has done to validate my support of him during his two terms. He's very much disappointed me.
I wish just one time people would list the policies of President Obama they are against.

The point about Spanish is interesting.  I do not know, nor have I seen, any information about these particular migrants but, to the extent they come from (especially) rural areas in Guatemala or Honduras, Spanish may very well be their second language.  Native tongues are still the principal language of many areas of these countries.  Anyway, language is just another complicating factor in this whole story.

Yes, health care is a cost to business, and they like to unload costs.

However, it is also a very effective tool of compensation. Workers can't get good health care any other way, and they know it. In wage bargaining, it is worth more than its marginal dollars cost.

It also gives the employer a tool of control -- give up or lose this job, and you lose your doctor too, and your kids' doctor, and your spouse's doctor. It keeps people in line.

Cunning human resources guys don't want to lose that power. They see it as false economy, since they'd have to pay more for the same recruiting and control of employees they have with control of health care.
